choices.text: Fusion reflex developed fully at birth

questions.text: All are true about eyeball in neonates except
questions.solution:
• Newborns have hypermetropia and shallow anterior chamber as length of eyeball is small.
  • Fusion reflex starts developing by 2-3 weeks after birth and completed by 2 months

questions.text: What is this structure shown in the image
questions.solution:
Canal of petit: The space between post equatorial and hyaloid zonules

  • Canal of Hannover: The narrow space between pre-equatorial and post- equatorial zonules.
  • Berger's space: space located between posterior capsule of lens and the anterior hyaloid of vitreous, structures that adhere in circular manner by means of the Wiegert ligament, for which the outer limit is Eggers's line
  • Pseudoexfoliative material can accumulate itself on the pupillary boundary which makes pupillary dilation difficult, can get deposited on zonules causing sudden sublaxation of lens during surgery (as it makes lens weak)

choices.text: Methylene blue dye can be used to stain the anterior capsule lens
Viscoelastics are used so that they keep visual field clear

questions.text: What is correct about cataract surgery
questions.solution:
To stain anterior capsule during continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis tryptan blue dye is used.

Viscoelastics are used to maintain anterior chamber

Uses of viscoelastics :

  • Keep AC maintained and pressurized during main incision creation
  • Maintain anterior chamber depth and keeps the anterior lens capsule flat during capsulorrhexis creation
  • Protects corneal epithelium during phacoemulsification. It will coat and protect the corneal endothelium
  • Lubricate the IOL and the injector system
  • Dilates the pupils as well

FLACS uses Femto laser which has Nd glass laser

Argon green is used for photocoagulation

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

questions.text: A 20 year old male presents with complaints of diminished night vision since two years. On fundus examination, he was found to have features of retinitis pigmentosa. Systemic examination showed obesity, mental defect, polydactyly and hypogonadism. What is the most probable syndrome he's suffering from?
questions.solution:
Usher syndrome is the most common syndrome associated with retinitis pigmentosa, but it classically presents with sensorineural hearing loss


Retinitis pigmentosa presents with a triad of bony spicules, attenuation of blood vessels, pale disc.

IOC is ERG

choices.text: Excimer laser is used to make lenticule
Femtolaser used to make smile shaped incision
Done for mild to moderate myopia
Dry eye chances are very less

questions.text: What is not true about this surgery
questions.solution:
The given image is of SMILE surgery (small incisional lenticule extraction)

Cornea is made thinner by taking out lenticule.

Lenticule is made by creating a smile shaped incision using Femto laser. It is a flapless, bladeless surgery.

It is used in mild to moderate myopia patients

As length of incision is very small, chances of dry eye is also very less.

Excimer laser is used in LASIK

choices.text: Bilateral cup to disc ratio of 0.7
Cup to disc ratio of 0.6:1 with notch formation in optic nerve rim

questions.text: What would be the most important finding suggestive of glaucoma in a patient with elevated intraocular pressure?
questions.solution:
• Although a cup-to-disc ratio asymmetry of 0.1 to 0.2 may be normal, a difference greater than 0.2 is suggestive of glaucoma.
  • A bilateral cup-to-disc ratio of 0.7 does not necessarily indicate glaucoma. This can be seen in individuals with very large optic nerves and accompanying large optic cups.
  • The depth of the optic cup has very little correlation with glaucoma and glaucomatous optic nerve damage.
  • A cup-to-disc ratio of 0.4 : 1 may not arouse much suspicion for glaucoma; however, if accompanied by elevated intraocular pressure and notch formation in the optic nerve rim, it would be strongly suggestive of glaucomatous optic nerve damage.

Reference: Yanoff and Duker 4th edition/1026

questions.text: What is this type of lens
questions.solution:
• In conventional PHACO, only distant vision can be corrected. Glasses should be used post surgery for correction of near vision.
  • By using accommodative lens i.e., crysta lens near vision can also be corrected. 1mm of anterior movement of lens = 1.80 D of accommodation.
  • Special type of IOL's
  • Multifocal IOL : Has multiple rings in it. Each ring has specific focal length. All visions can be corrected by multifocal IOL. Sometimes, patient can develop colored haloes

Special type of IOL's

  • A) Square edge: Decreases chance of PCO
  • B) Aspheric: Corrects all spherical aberrations
  • C) Heparin coated: used in uveitis patients as it decreases inflammation
  • D) Toric IOL: Corrects pre-existing astigmatism

questions.text: Most common cause of moderate-severe vision impairment according to 2015-19 survey?
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of mild vision impairment is refractive errors
  • Most common cause of moderate-severe vision impairment is cataract

choices.text: To measure exact amount of squint

questions.text: What is the use of this instrument given in the figure
questions.solution:
Instrument shown in the question is of Maddox rod

Maddox rod is used to check for phoria (latent squint). It breaks the fusion of images in patient with latent phoria and he/she can see 2 different images which are unfused

It has horizontal lines which would break a point source of light into vertical red lines and latent squint is manifested

Orthophoria is seen in normal individuals

Exophoria is known as crossed diplopia

Esophoria is known as uncrossed diplopia

questions.text: A 25 year old male with a small pupil, IOP of 25mmHg, mild flare and cells in anterior chamber with hazy cornea and shallow Anterior chamber in fellow eye came to you. What is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Small pupil is a keyword in this question to differentiate between anterior uveitis and angle closure glaucoma as angle closure glaucoma has mid dilated pupil

Other options

c) Incipient cataract : it is early stage of cortical cataract where we see change in refractive index, there is no rise in IOP, flare and cells in the anterior chamber

d) Secondary glaucoma : it cant be secondary glaucoma as there is nothing mentioned about history of trauma/drugs/surgery

choices.text: Usually between the ages of 5 and 10 years, and increases steadily up to 25 years or beyond

questions.text: Pathological axial myopia is
questions.solution:
• Pathological axial myopia is degenerative and progressive.
  • The refractive change appears in childhood, usually between the ages of 5 and 10 years, and increases steadily up to 25 years or beyond, finally amounting to -15 or -25 D or more.
  • The degenerative changes in the fundus, on the other hand, do not appear until later in life, becoming marked at about the fifth decade.
  • The condition is strongly hereditary, being commoner in women than in men. It has a racial predilection, being common, for example, among Jews and Japanese and most cases are of genetic origin.
  • Many other aetiological theories have been advanced excessive accommodation and convergence in near work, vascular congestion due to a dependent position of the head, and so on but they have little to recommend them.
  • The condition is essentially a disturbance of growth on which are imposed the degenerative phenomena; these will be considered at a later stage
  • Endocrine or nutritional disturbances, debility or illness, probably act as incidental factors which may increase the general tendency; but, despite popular belief which still lingers, environmental conditions such as excessive near work probably have little influence upon the condition which is genetically pre-determined, except in so far as they inhibit normal healthy development.

Reference: Parson ch 8, P. 75

choices.text: Haemorrhagic component Intraretinal hemorrhages, venous beading, and intraretinal microvascular abnormalities

questions.text: Which of the following are defining characteristics of severe non proliferative diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
Intraretinal hemorrhages, venous beading, and intraretinal microvascular abnormalities are typical features of severe non proliferative diabetic retinopathy. Retinal neovascularization, vitreous hemorrhage, and tractional retinal detachment are features of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

Reference: Kanski 8th edition/521

questions.text: A 4-year-old male shown here is referred for evaluation of congenital ptosis. Which of the following abnormal examination findings would you expect to see?
questions.solution:
• A patient with congenital ptosis will present with minimal to absent levator function, often with an absent lid crease.
  • Frontalis function is normal.
  • Patients with aponeurotic ptosis present with an abnormally high lid crease secondary to levator dehiscence.

Reference: kurana 4/e, p. 67

choices.text: Rapid improvement in traumatic diplopia over a 24 hour period
Unilateral midfacial sensory loss (V2 distribution unilaterally)

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most commonly associated with orbital floor fractures?
questions.solution:
• Optic nerve injury is not associated with orbital floor fractures.
  • Enopthalmos is not an early but late finding as orbital contents would be going down into the maxillary sinus .
  • Diplopia develops early and persists for longer duration.
  • Infraorbital nerve is injured in orbital floor fractures, therefore unilateral mid-facial sensory loss is seen along distribution of V2.
  • Radiological finding seen in orbital floor fracture(blow out fracture) : tear drop sign

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for development of Acanthamoeba Keratitis?
questions.solution:
Acanthamoebic keratitiscan be a devastating infection if not recognized early. Its occurrence is frequently associated with the wearing of soft contact lenses. The usual source of infection is the saline solution used to clean or store the lenses. It has also been seen to occur in noncontact lens wearers and may be related to swimming or bathing in contaminated water. There may be no antecedent trauma.

Tap water/ contaminated water/ contaminated saline solutions if used for lens washing/ storage predispose to infection.

Reference: Parson's diseases of the Eye-Chap 12 - Diseases of Cornea.

questions.text: A girl came to OPD after LASIK. What would be her IOP on applanation now as compared to pre op reading.
questions.solution:
• Goldmann applanation tonometry is calibrated for normal cornea with corneal thickness of 520µm
  • Post LASIK as cornea is thinned out, false low reading of IOP is seen
  • Correction of IOP in falsely low IOP :
    • For every 10µm thinness of cornea, add 1 to recorded IOP
  • Correction of IOP in falsely thick IOP:
    • For every 10µm thickness of cornea, subtract 1 to recorded IOP

questions.text: A female presented with a sudden painless loss of vision. She has no history of DM/ hypertension. On examination direct and consensual light reflex are normal. Retina also shows no changes but her VEP is subnormal. She is also having anxiety and depressive episodes and had been seeking psychologist treatment. What is your provisional diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Cortical blindness patients present with sudden painless loss of vision
  • Pupillary reflexes are normal in cortical blindness as pupillary fibres doesn't pass through visual cortex
  • Other options :
    • B) Malingering : It cant be malingering as VEP is sub-normal
    • C) Retrobulbar neuritis : as pupillary reflexes are normal it cant be retrobulbar neuritis, we see RAPD in retrobulbar neuritis
    • D) Papilloedema : as retina is normal, it cant be papilloedema

questions.text: What is the muscle responsible for dextro-elevation
questions.solution:
• Dextro = right, elevation = upwards.

Yolk muscles responsible for dextro-elevation would be right superior rectus and left inferior oblique, right lateral rectus and left medial rectus

choices.text: Absence of sweating on same side of face

questions.text: A patient is found to have a mild ptosis which he reports to have since birth. There is also change in the color of iris of the same eye. What is not likely feature associated with this condition
questions.solution:
Patient with mid ptosis, change in color of iris of same eye is seen in HORNERS SYNDROME

Pneumonic - HI PAMELA

HI - Heterochromia iridium( less pigmented iris on the affected side).


  • P: Ptosis, or drooping of the upper eyelid
  • A: Anhidrosis, or lack of sweating
  • M: Miosis, or constricted pupil
  • E: Enophthalmos, or sunken eyeball
  • L: Loss of ciliary-spinal reflex, which is the dilation of the pupils when the neck is pinched
  • A: Anisocoria (irregular pupil size)
  • Not a likely feature associated wit this condition would be option A - LPS ( Levator palpebrae superioris) muscle weakness.

questions.text: A patient with gradual decrease of vision for distance since few years. He claims his near vision is improved now. On Slit lamp examination this was seen. What is the most likely cause of his refractive condition
questions.solution:
This phenomenon is seen in Nuclear cataract. The formation of nuclear cataract is seen in the image as brownish discoloration of lens.

This is also known as Second site of old age.

Index myopia is the refractive error found in Nuclear cataract.

In nuclear cataract patient behaves like a myope (one with myopia), so patient develops good near vision

Once the patient has a good near vision then they would not require any glasses to read.

choices.text: Staining of anterior capsule in cataract

questions.text: What is least common use of fluorescein dye in ophthalmology
questions.solution:
Fluorescein dye is used in Applanation tonometry. Cornea is stained using the Fluorescein dye

B -Fluorescein dye used in Measurement of TBUT ( tear film breakup time ) to test for dry eye.

C - fluorescein is used in FFA(fundus fluorescein angiography fluorescein)

D -Trypan blue dye used for staining of anterior capsule in cataract but not fluoresceine.

  • Rose Bengal dye

Stains dead and devitalized tissue, Now thought to stain any part of the ocular surface which is not protected by an overlying tear film

Surface irritation and discomfort.

Surface cytotoxicity is also one of the factors behind its limited use in routine practice.



  • Lissamine green 1-2%

Doesn't stain healthy corneal surface

  • for staining dead and degenerated cells, including mucous strands.
  • Use of a green (red-free) filter shows the stained areas to appear black in color.
  • As it is better tolerated than rose bengal, it is the preferred dye for staining the bulbar conjunctiva.

questions.text: A 55 year old male developed pain and redness in RE after a parotid tumour surgery on the same side. What can be the most likely diagnosis seeing the picture.
questions.solution:
Parotid tumor surgery may sometimes lead to iatrogenic facial nerve injury. Facial nerve damage causes inability to close the eyelid(lagopthalmos).

Inability to close the eyelid predisposes the eye to injury which may lead to ulcer development.

Patient may develop dry eye in the inferior part of cornea.


Treatment include - putting tear drops, patching the eye, or tarsorrhaphy- surgical closure of the eyelid. So the ulcers that develop due to damage of the nerve are called as neuroparalytic ulcers.


C - severe dry eye can develop due to the damage of facial nerve but the patient has pain and redness which is indicative of Ulcer. Dry eye can present with ocular irritation but not with pain.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with flashes and floaters. In retina a lesion was seen. Treatment of this condition
questions.solution:
Image shows Lattice degeneration which is criss cross degeneration in the mid peripheral part of retina.

High myopia higher the chance of retinal thinning, higher are the chances of having this degenerative changes.

This patient with symptoms of flashes and floaters has developed a tear in the degenerative area.

If the image shown was an incidental finding without any symptoms then we could just wait and watch till the patient develops symptoms

Treatment - laser Barrage, in this technique we scar the damaged part.


A - Pan retinal laser would not be a good option for this condition as if focal in retina.

questions.text: Bronze beaten appearance of retina is seen in
questions.solution:
Bronze beaten appearance of retina is seen in Stargardt's disease.


Stargardt's disease - Autosomal Recessive condition.

Associated with ABCA4 gene mutation

It is seen In children, where there is accumulation of lipofuschin in the retina. Patient presents with symptoms of gradual loss of vision.

The yellow - white lesions shown in the retina are called pisiform flecks.

BRONZE BEATEN APPEARANCE where there is bronze like material accumulation in the macula is seen in the late stages of Stargardt's disease. As macula is being affected central vision is lost.

When FFA is done we see a DARK/SILENT CHOROID, as the lipofuschin accumulates in the choroid, the choroid loses its fluorescein ability and appears dark on FFA.

questions.text: Normal conjunctival flora includes
questions.solution:
The most common organism in the normal conjunctival flora is Staph epidermis.

Most common ocular surface bacteria are Coagulase- negative Staphylococci which are present in 20-80% of the swabs from conjunctiva and 30-100% of the swabs from the lids.

Other commensal in eye include Chamydophila pneumoniae, Haemophilus aegyptius, Hemophilus influenzae, Moraxella spp, Neisseria spp, Staphylococcus aureus, streptococcus viridians.

Most common organism of early endopthalmitis is Coagulase negative Staphylococci. Best prophylaxis to prevent it is to apply 5% povidone Iodine.

choices.text: lt is a 1-2mm wide zone as junction of cornea and sclera
It has stem cells in basal corneal epithelium
Incision is made at limbus for cataract surgery
Superior rectus muscle is closest to limbus

questions.text: Mark the wrong statement about limbus
questions.solution:
TRUE STATEMENTS ABOUT LIMBUS

It is a 1-2mm wide zone as junction of cornea and sclera

It has stem cells in basal corneal epithelium.

Incision is made at limbus mostly in the superior part as it is thicker than inferior part of limbus for cataract surgery.

Medial Rectus is closest to limbus, it is 5mm apart from limbus. As it is closest to limbus, it has more chance of injury during the surgery

Inferior rectus in 6.5mm apart from limbus.

Lateral rectus is 6.9mm apart from limbus.

Superior rectus is 7.7mm apart from limbus, farthest from limbus.

choices.text: Red glass in front of left eye
If 5 dots are seen, it indicates diplopia

questions.text: Worth four dot test
questions.solution:
WORTH FOUR DOT TEST is used for Binocular vision.

It has 2 green dots, 1 red dot, 1 white dot to be visualised.

Test includes placing of red glass in front of the right eye, green glass in front of the left eye.

If there is Right eye suppression, only 3 green dots are seen.

If there is Left eye suppression, only 2 red dots are seen.

If the patient sees 3 green dots, 2 red dots or 3 red dots, 2 green dots, it indicates the patient has diplopia.

questions.text: False about papillitis is
questions.solution:
Papillitis - inflammation of the intraocular part of the Optic Disc.

It can present with vision loss.

As itis indicate inflammation, Disc swelling is noted.

RAPD( relative afferent pupillary defect) is also seen in papillitis.

Headache and vomiting is not associated with Papillitis. Vomiting and headache are common presenting symptoms in Papilledema.

Treatment for the condition is I.V methylprednisolone.

questions.text: Regarding WTR astigmatism true is
questions.solution:
Features of With the rule astigmatism -

steep axis is at 90 degrees.

Flat meridian is horizontal.

Plus cylinder is at 90 degrees.

It is treated with Cylindrcial numbers.

AGAINST THE ASTIGMATISM.

Steep axis is at 180 degrees

Flat meridian is vertical.

choices.text: h/o redness and pain earlier may be there in the affected eye

questions.text: False about complicated cataract:
questions.solution:
Complicated cataracts are seen secondary to any ocular cause.

Uveitis is the most common cause of secondary Cataract.

Glare is the main complaint in cataract.

h/o redness and pain may be seen in the affected eye with secondary cataract.

Polychromatic lustre, bread crump appearance are seen in secondary cataract.

Polychromatic lustre


bread crump appearance


Floret appearance is seen in traumatic cataracts.
